metadata.title: Synthesis and characterization of Ag@Carbon core-shell spheres as a novel catalyst for room temperature N-arylation reaction

Synthesis and characterization of Ag@Carbon core-shell spheres as a novel catalyst for room temperature N-arylation reaction Seyedeh Mozhgan Seyed-Talebi a Iraj Kazeminezhad a b ⁎ Manijeh Nematpour c a Department of Physics, Faculty of Science, Shahid Chamran University of Ahvaz, Ahvaz, Iran Department of Physics Faculty of Science Shahid Chamran University of Ahvaz Ahvaz Iran b Center for Research on Laser and Plasma, Shahid Chamran University of Ahvaz, Ahvaz, Iran Center for Research on Laser and Plasma Shahid Chamran University of Ahvaz Ahvaz Iran c Department of Chemistry, Tarbiat Modares University, Tehran, Iran Department of Chemistry Tarbiat Modares University Tehran Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The Ag@Carbon core-shell spheres were synthesized using a green, cheap, and easy process. The products were characterized by XRD, FESEM, TEM, MAP, EDX, Raman, and FT-IR analysis. The synthesis of a novel class of trichloro-1-nitroprop-1-en-2-amine via our Ag@Carbon spheres as a new Ag-catalyzed multicomponent reaction of nitroalkane-trichloroacetonitrile adduct and aryl halides in good yields under mild reaction conditions is reported. The catalytic activity of core-shell spheres was determined by changing the solvent and catalyst. The effect of solvent was investigated by performing the model reaction in the presence of catalyst in various conditions with DMF, DMSO, Toluene, THF, acetone and acetonitrile solvents. Among them, acetonitrile was found to be the best solvent in terms of the reaction time and yield of desired product. A comprehensive catalytic analysis of Ag@Carbon with Ag nanoparticles and carbon spheres as references and commercial AgI, AgBr, AgNO3, and Ag2SO4 as Ag based catalysts has been performed. Keywords Ag-catalyst Carbon sphere Core-shell Hydrothermal method N-Arylation Trichloro-1-nitroprop-1-en-2-amine 1 Introduction The part of materials science and solid state physics related to the carbon materials is a highly interesting topic, due to their unique chemical and physical properties [1–8]. Among these carbon forms, spherical particles such as carbon spheres and core-shell spheres have received more and more attention owing to their unique structure and physical properties such as encapsulation ability, controllable permeability, surface functionality, high surface to volume ratios, and excellent chemical stabilities [9–15]. These properties make core-shell structures attractive for various applications ranging from optical sensors, colloidal catalysts, and hard templates to drug carriers, adsorbents, gas storage, fuel cells, super capacitors and lithium-based batteries [16–19]. Recently, various articles have been published about carbon spheres preparation and their applications [13,15]. In the same time, various articles have discussed advancement in synthesis of noble metal@carbon core-shell particles and their applications [20–22]. However, there exists no special study about catalytic activity of these core-shell structures. Herein, efforts were made to successfully test the sub-micron size Ag@Carbon particles as catalyst. In this procedure, carbon shell protects the silver nano particles from light and moisture and retains the surface functional groups for loading other functional groups onto them. In an attempt to find out the effect of carbon shell on the catalytic activity of Ag@Carbon, the test was performed on carbon spheres as a reference. The results exhibited that the carbon sphere did not show any catalytic activity response. Therefore, the catalytic activity of Ag@Carbon core-shell structures is related to the encapsulated Ag inside the carbon shells. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time to use encapsulated Ag ions inside carbon spheres as catalysts. In the current work, we reported the synthesis of two core-shell spheres by using sucrose for a novel catalysis application that both of them have a carbon shell, but with different types of core (Fig. 1 ). In the first step, the Ag-catalyzed core-shell spheres were synthesized using simple hydrothermal method. In the second step, they were characterized by several methods and the results were compared to those of carbon spheres as the reference sample. At the end, the catalytic performance of our Ag@Carbon catalyst in the N-arylation reaction was compared to the results belonging to the other Ag-based catalysts. The formation of aryl-N bond plays an important role in the synthesis of organic compounds that are of biological, pharmaceutical, and materials interests[23–27]. In the absence of a catalysts, no CN coupling occurs at room temperature. Despite significant improvements in various catalysts such as CuI, palladium, nickel, Copper and copper ferrite and ZnO during the past years [28–37]. Their usage has some limitations in many cases such as high temperatures, the air and moisture sensitivity, sensitivity to functional groups on the aryl halide, long reaction times, strongly acidic conditions, as well as the high cost of catalysts and the relative ligands. Our interest in this area stems from an experimentally development of a ligand-free catalytic system for CN formation protocol by Ag-catalyst. In this article, a class of one-pot, ligand-free, room temperature, three-component reactions of nitroalkane (R-CH2-NO2; R = H or Me), trichloroacetonitrile and various aryl halides (ArX; X = I or Br) for the synthesis of trichloro-1-nitroprop-1-en-2-yl aniline has been described. The general protocol of these new reactions in presence of Ag@carbon core-shell spheres as Ag catalyst is illustrated in Fig. 2 . 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Materials All the chemicals were used as received: Silver nitrate (AgNO3; 99.99%), Sucrose ((C12H22O11)n) and ethanol were obtained commercially from Merck company of analytical grade. Trichloro acetonitrile (Cl3CCN: 98%), Acetonitrile (CH3CN: 98%), Nitromethane (CH3NO2: 98%), (Nitroethan: CH3CH2NO2: 98%), Iodobenzene (C6H5I: 98%), 4-Iodotoluene (CH3C6H4I: 99%), 1-Bromo-4-iodobenzene (BrC6H4I: 98%), 4-Bromobenzonitrile (BrC6H4CN: 99%), 1-Bromo-3-nitrobenzene (C6H4BrNO2: 99%), 1-Chloro-4-iodobenzene (ClC6H4I: 99%), 4-Iodoanisole (IC6H4OCH3: 98%), 4-Bromotoluene (CH3C6H4Br: 98%), Sodium hydride dry (NaH: 95%), Potassium carbonate (K2CO3: 99%) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and used without further purification. For all the preparation steps, Deionized (DI) water with pH 6.4–6.5 was used. 2.2 Sample preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of carbon sphere Preparation of carbon sphere using hydrothermal methods was described elsewhere [13,21]. In a typical synthesis of colloidal carbon spheres, sucrose was dissolved in deionized water to form a clear solution (85 mL, 0.1 M), which was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Then it was sealed and heated at 190 °C for 4 h. When the reaction was completed, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, and the black or brown precipitate was collected and washed by centrifugation at 6000 rpm for 20 min with deionized water and ethanol for three times, and the final product was dried at 45 °C for 10 h. We did not employ any catalyst or template in the preparation of these particles. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Ag@Carbon In a typical procedure, both AgNO3 and sucrose were dissolved in deionized water, resulting in a clear and homogeneous solution. 1 mL portion of AgNO3 aqueous solution (0.1 M) was added drop-by-drop into the above-mentioned 0.1 M sucrose solution using a syringe pump at an injection rate of 6 mL h−1. After stirring for more 10 min, the solution was transferred and sealed in a Teflon-sealed autoclave and heated to 190 °C for 4 h before being cooled in air naturally. The resulting products were centrifuged, washed, redispersed in deionized water and ethanol three times. After that, the products were oven dried at 50 °C. The formation of Ag@Carbon core-shell structures involved two primary steps: nucleation of inner silver nanoparticles, and consequent epitaxial growth and thickening of carbonaceous shell on the silver core. The presence of carbonaceous material in the preparation process acts as a barrier and prevents Ag particles from agglomeration leading to the long-term stability. Thus, Ag+ ions sustained release can be controlled by tunable thickness of carbon shell. Generally, it is very difficult to study the exact chemical reactions in an autoclave under hydrothermal conditions. A possible formation mechanism for Ag@carbon core-shell structure can be proposed as follows. In our approach, commercial soluble sucrose, (C12H22O11)n, acts as the carbon sources and AgNO3 salts acts as the catalyst and source of the Ag to be encapsulated. 2.2.3 The formation mechanism of the Ag@Carbon structures under hydrothermal conditions At the beginning, the sucrose solution can reduce the AgNO3 salt. The reduction of Ag ions lead to formation of unstable Ag nanoparticles. Then, these nanoparticles grow larger, and their shape evolve into triangular/hexagonal- shaped nuclei [19,38,39]. At the same time, the remaining sucrose molecules form the aromatic compounds and partly are transformed into graphitic-like carbon materials. Owing to a higher affinity of carbon for oxygen than Ag, the carbonaceous sheets will solidify long before the inner Ag to form the carbon shells. Therefore, the Ag core will encapsulate by carbon shells through carbonization of sucrose. This solid shell around the liquid Ag allows the Ag to crystallize undisturbed from the outer atmosphere. The growing of Ag surface along some directions stops by deposited carbonaceous sheets. In other directions, Ag ions can easily enter into the interface between carbon surfaces due to the relatively weak interactions between the surface and Ag ions. These growth processes occur at the same time and are tightly coupled to each other. Thus, after formation of the shell, some silver ions had also adsorbed onto the shell surface. These were likely oxidized after exposure of the particles to the air. 2.3 Characterization techniques Using several tools, the quality of the resulting powders was checked. The crystal phase and morphology of the products were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, PW-1840 Philips) diffractometer at room temperature by CuKα radiation (wavelength of λ = 0.15418 nm) in the range of 2θ = 10–90 °C, Raman spectroscopy by Teksan (Tekram P50C0R10) Raman microscope (λ = 532 nm, 10–90 Mw) at 25 °C and the FESEM (Tescan Mira3 FESEM). Using Digimizer software, the average particle size was measured by calibration using the FESEM image scale bar. In this procedure the size of at least 250 particles was measured for each sample with this software and the average value was reported as size of the particles. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on a Zeiss-EM10C-100 kV microscope. The Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra were performed using a PerkinElmer Spectrometer in the wavenumbers of 4000–500 cm−1 employing KBr pellets to identify the functional groups and chemical bonding of the particles. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and morphology studies Fig. 3 shows the X-ray diffraction pattern of the Ag@Carbon core-shell spheres in comparison to the carbon sphere's. The X-ray pattern of the carbon spheres is demonstrated by the wide diffraction peaks around 2θ ∼ 22.9° (d ≈ 3.88 Å) and 2θ ∼ 43.1° (d ≈ 2.1 Å) which can be indexed as typical graphitic (0 0 2) and (1 0 0) planes. However, existence of only these two peaks of graphite structure and their broadening implies the low graphitization degree and the possible presence of amorphous carbon. Accordingly, the carbon spheres contained some graphite-like amorphous structures [13]. Furthermore, in the core-shell's X-ray pattern, the intensity of the (0 0 2) peak of carbon decreased and the peak at 2θ ∼ 43.1° was not observed which is attributed to the lower graphitization degree of carbon shells. It could also be proposed that these core-shell spheres consisted of short curved graphite-like layers. The possible reason for this is coexistence of sp3 bonded carbon and sp2 bonded carbon in these structures. The presence of sp3 bond can change the distance of carbon layers and lead to formation of curved structures [40]. In addition, it can be observed that there are also five sharp peaks in the X-ray pattern of Ag @ Carbon located at 2θ of 38.05°, 44.13°, 64.29°, 77.18° and 81.35°. These main peaks belong to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0), (3 1 1) and (2 2 2) Ag's crystalline plane reflections. The peaks of silver could be indexed to the face-centred cubic crystal structures (JCPDS 04-0783), while no diffraction due to silver oxide was observed. The XRD results were found in good agreement with the other reported measurements [18–22]. The average crystallite size of Ag in the core-shell spheres is also estimated from the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of (1 1 1) reflection peak using Scherrer equation (1) D hkl = K λ β hkl cos θ hkl where K was a dimensionless shape factor (a constant about 0.9), λ was the X-ray wavelength for copper radiation (0.15418 nm), β hkl is the FWHM of the diffraction line, and θ is the Bragg angle (in degrees). β and θ were taken from (1 1 1) diffraction line [41]. The average size of Ag crystallites for the product was approximately 18 nm. It indicates that the core of Ag@Carbon particles is formed by aggregation of several Ag nanocrystalites with sizes of approximately 18 nm. It was also found that in the carbon shell the interlayer spacing value d(0 0 2) = 3.88 Å increased compared to the graphite due to the small number of carbon atoms per lamellae. The high d spacing value of carbon shell was found in agreement with the reported measurements (3.5 Å-4 Å) revealed by TEM [42,43]. Fig. 4 shows typical FESEM images of sub-micron sized carbon spheres and Ag@Carbon core-shell spheres. The diameters of the carbon spheres were influenced by reaction time, temperature, pH and concentration of starting solutions [21]. The particle size distribution was determined to characterize how the particle size changed (Fig. 4). Carbon spheres had an average particle size as 186 nm; the average particle size became 290 nm in Ag@Carbon. It could be observed from the elemental mapping in the Fig. 5 a that the Ag core was well placed in the centre of the shells with an approximate large size of 290 nm. The MAP also clearly confirms the existence of carbon in the shell. Fig. 5b presents the data obtained from EDX spectrum of one single Ag@Carbon core-shell spheres. The spectra clearly demonstrated that the core-shell particles consisted of silver and carbon. The component ratio is in agreement with the molar fraction of Ag in product and the volume of AgNO3 solution that was added to react with sucrose precursor. The narrow size distributions of the core-shell spheres were also demonstrated by TEM observations. Fig. 5c shows a typical TEM image of such Ag@carbon spheres. The relative higher contrast of the shell with respect to the centre zone confirms that the particles have a core-shell structure. Most of Ag cores in Fig. 5c formed hexagonal structures. The TEM analysis showed an average outer diameter of 250 ± 20 nm for Ag cores and an average shell thickness of 65 ± 5 nm. The diameters of the carbon shells were influenced by reaction time, temperature, and concentration of starting material. To study allotropic form of the carbon phase, the Raman spectroscopy was applied, which was considered to be a sensitive tool for analysis of carbon containing materials. Fig. 6 presents a comparison between Raman spectra of carbon spheres and Ag@Carbons. The spectra of two samples are similar to each other consisting of two broad overlapping peaks at 1369 and 1571 that can be assigned to the D and G bands of the disordered and graphitized carbons, respectively [44]. The shape of these bands depends on the sample crystallite sizes. When the crystallites become larger, the peaks become narrower and the intensity of the G-band substantially increases in comparison to the intensity of the D-band [30]. The G peak is associated with out-of-phase vibrations of pairs of carbon atoms in different structural elements (rings, chains) and is related to the vibration of the sp2 hybridized carbon atoms in the disordered graphite-like structures. The D peak corresponds to the “breathing” mode of carbon rings, manifesting itself in the presence of a disorder [45]. The changes in the Raman spectra of the amorphous carbons can be related to the presence of sp3 bond and bending of the nano graphite-like layers [46]. The relative intensity ratio (ID/IG), called graphitization degree, is an indication of the degree of disorder in graphitic structures. These ratios were found to be 0.53 and 0.6 for Ag@Carbon and carbon spheres, respectively which is ascribed to bond bending due to the shell curvature. This low intensity of ID/IG value of the particles implies the decreasing graphitic degree of carbons in the structures. The value of Ag@Carbon core-shell sphere (0.53) is lower than that of carbon sphere (0.6), suggesting more defect into the Ag@Carbon structure after hydrothermal process. It could be also due to a lower lattice mismatch between Ag core and carbon shell in comparison to the carbon sphere's which is in good agreement with our XRD results. Fig. 7 shows the Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) corresponding to two samples. The spectra contain small differences between IR bands of carbon sphere and Ag@Carbon core-shell structures, indicating that carbon sphere and carbon in the shell of Ag@Carbon spheres have a similar chemical nature. The bands, falling into the ranges of 3400–3450 cm−1 and 1000–1450 cm−1, could be attributed to the OH (hydroxyl or carboxyl) stretching vibration and CO (hydroxyl) stretching and OH bending vibrations respectively, indicating the existence of a large number of hydroxy (OH) groups on the surfaces. Whereas the bands at approximately 2900 cm−1 correspond to stretching vibrations of aliphatic CH. The bands at 1704 cm−1 and 1618 cm−1 can be attributed to CO (carbonyl or carboxyl) and CC vibrations respectively [13,47]. A comparative analysis of the FT-IR spectra of the samples suggests that dehydration and aromatization processes occur during the hydrothermal carbonization. Thus, the intensities of the bands corresponding to the hydroxyl or carboxyl groups (3000–3700 cm−1 and 1000–1450 cm−1) in the Ag@Carbon are weaker than those of the corresponding carbon sphere, thereby disclosing dehydration reactions. The intensity of vibration bands at 1704 cm−1, corresponding to CO groups in carbon sphere is more than that of the Ag@Carbon core-shell structure. A decrease in the wide band at approximately 3429 cm−1 (OH), is due to oxygen removal from the surface of Ag@Carbon[48]. 3.2 Catalysts measurements and mechanism. Our work began with the intention of developing general conditions for a model reaction shown in the Fig. 2. The nitromethane 1a, trichloroacetonitrile 2a, and iodobenzene 3a have selected as components of the new reaction 5a. This reaction in room temperature does not occur in the absence of added catalyst. Table 1 shows the optimization of reaction conditions by changing the solvent and catalysts. It was revealed that the catalytic activity of the Ag@Carbon core-shell structures is the best for this reaction compared to the commercial AgI, AgBr, AgNO3 and Ag2SO4 as Ag based catalysts. By the comparison between catalytic activity of Ag based materials in the metallic and ionic forms of the Ag, the impact of ionic silver (Ag+) in our core-shell materials would be more significant. Our results confirm that Ag in non-ionized (Ag0) and Ag+2 ion forms does not exhibit any catalytic activity in the new reactions. Therefore, the need for Ag to have any catalysis property in this reaction, it must be in its ionic form of Ag+. Furthermore, the oxidation of Ag+ to Ag+2 is the most important factor in changing Ag+ to Ag+2 and decreasing the catalytic activity of Ag+-catalysts. We believe that carbon shell in the core-shell structures causes Ag+ protection against oxidation. The large surface area and more provided porosity of the carbon shell in Ag core-shell structures are other reasons for the significant increase in the catalytic efficiency of Ag@carbon core-shell spheres. In the case of used AgI and AgBr catalysts, the I− ion is a better leaving group as compared to the Br− ion. Therefore , the reactions in the presence of AgI gave better yields than AbBr catalyst. The optimized reaction conditions were found to be 10 mol % of Ag@Carbon as the catalyst, 1.5 mmol of K2CO3 and 1.0 mmol of NaH as the base, 1 mmol of trichloroacetonitrile and 1 mmol of nitromethane in MeCN at room temperature, under N2 atmosphere. The reactions under other solvents were invariably resulted lower yields. Our continuing studies in this area using optimized conditions have led to the synthesis of new compounds which are listed in Table 2 . A possible reaction mechanism for a typical new compound 5a in presence of our Ag-catalyst is shown in Fig. 8 . It is proposed that compound 4a formed from nitromethane 1a, trichloroacetonitrile 2a, oxidative addition of iodobenzene 1a and Ag+ leads to intermediate 6. Treatment of 6 with compound 4a provides 7 in the presence of base (K2CO3), and reductive elimination of 7 affords N-arylation product 5a leaving silver catalyst. 3.3 Reusability of catalyst To study reusability of the catalysts, a typical reaction (Table 2, entry1) was selected. After completion of the reaction, the separated catalysts was washed twice with absolute ethanol and then was used for the same reaction. The experiments for the N-arylation were performed six times, each time using the same catalyst (duly separated from the earlier lot). After accomplishing the reaction, the Ag@Carbon core-shell structures were separated from the medium, then washed, centrifuged, dried and used for another reaction run. In this way, the recyclability of our synthesized Ag@Carbon core-shell structures was examined. The results are depicted in Fig. 9 . The results showed that Ag@carbon core-shell catalyst has an excellent reusability for these reactions. 4 Conclusions A simple hydrothermal method was used for the synthesis of carbon sphere and Ag@Carbon core-shell structures directly from nontoxic materials. The Ag@Carbon as a novel Ag-catalyzed one-pot carbon-nitrogen bond formation for the synthesis of trichloro-1-nitroprop-1-en-2-yl aniline starting from aryl halides, nitroalkane and trichloroacetonitrile in good yields under mild reaction free ligand conditions is successfully established. We examined a variety of Ag based materials and reactions. The tests resulted in an exclusive CN bond formation by an inexpensive, green and easy synthesized Ag@carbon core- shell catalyst. This research showed that our new catalyst performs better than commercial catalysts on the market which made from expensive, toxic and rare metals in their crystalline structures. The decrease in the catalytic activity of commercial Ag sources may be associated with the deactivation of the silver surface by adsorption of oxygen and Ag+ converted to Ag+2. While the core-shell spheres themselves catalyse the localized transformation of the particles into spherical Ag cores, that enclose the particles due to the intrinsic protective effect of carbon shell in the particles. The significant increase in catalytic efficiency was attributed to the large surface area and the porosity provided by the carbon shell. Appendix A Supplementary material Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcat.2018.02.029. coredata.dc:description: The Ag@Carbon core-shell spheres were synthesized using a green, cheap, and easy process. The products were characterized by XRD, FESEM, TEM, MAP, EDX, Raman, and FT-IR analysis. The synthesis of a novel class of trichloro-1-nitroprop-1-en-2-amine via our Ag@Carbon spheres as a new Ag-catalyzed multicomponent reaction of nitroalkane-trichloroacetonitrile adduct and aryl halides in good yields under mild reaction conditions is reported. The catalytic activity of core-shell spheres was determined by changing the solvent and catalyst. The effect of solvent was investigated by performing the model reaction in the presence of catalyst in various conditions with DMF, DMSO, Toluene, THF, acetone and acetonitrile solvents. Among them, acetonitrile was found to be the best solvent in terms of the reaction time and yield of desired product. A comprehensive catalytic analysis of Ag@Carbon with Ag nanoparticles and carbon spheres as references and commercial AgI, AgBr, AgNO3, and Ag2SO4 as Ag based catalysts has been performed.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis and characterization of Ag@Carbon core-shell spheres as a novel catalyst for room temperature N-arylation reaction
